questions.q: What are the two bursts that CPU schedulers are designed around?
questions.explanation: Execution consists of cycles of CPU processing and waiting for input/output.

questions.q: True or False? Under preemptive scheduling, a process may lose control of the CPU when switching to the ready state.
questions.explanation: True. Preemptive OSs can take the CPU away to give it to a higher-priority task.

questions.q: List at least three different criteria for designing a CPU scheduling algorithm.
questions.explanation: Other criteria include Waiting time and Response time.
questions.answer: CPU utilization, Throughput, and Turnaround time

questions.q: What scheduling algorithm assigns the CPU to the process with the highest priority?
questions.explanation: Higher priority processes are always given preference.

questions.q: True or False? The multilevel feedback queue allows processes to migrate between different queues.
questions.explanation: True. This allows the system to separate processes based on their CPU usage history.

questions.q: What scheduling algorithm assigns the CPU to the process that first requested it?
questions.explanation: This is the simplest algorithm, often implemented with a FIFO queue.

questions.q: What scheduling algorithm assigns the CPU to a process for only its time slice?
questions.explanation: RR is designed for time-sharing systems to provide equal time to all processes.

questions.q: What scheduling algorithm assigns the CPU to the process with the shortest burst?
questions.explanation: SJF provides the minimum average waiting time for a set of processes.

questions.q: What are the two types of contention scope for thread scheduling?
questions.explanation: PCS is for user threads within a process; SCS is for all threads in the system.

questions.q: What are the two general hardware instructions that can be performed atomically?
questions.explanation: These instructions are used to solve the critical-section problem in synchronization.

questions.q: What is more common on current systems, asymmetric or symmetric multiprocessing?
questions.explanation: SMP is standard for modern multi-core computers.

questions.q: What are the two forms of processor affinity?
questions.explanation: Soft affinity tries to keep a process on a processor; hard affinity forces it.

questions.q: What are the two general approaches for load balancing?
questions.explanation: Push migration moves tasks to idle CPUs; pull migration has idle CPUs take tasks from busy ones.

questions.q: What are the two ways to multithread a processing core?
questions.explanation: These methods manage how the core switches between threads on stalls.

questions.q: What real-time scheduling algorithm uses deadline as its scheduling criteria?
questions.explanation: EDF dynamically assigns priorities based on how soon a task must finish.

questions.q: What is the name of the default scheduling algorithm for current Linux systems?
questions.explanation: CFS uses a red-black tree to ensure all processes get a fair share of CPU time.
